channel.title: Designs for 'Yell' (Force Chat)
channel.description:
Throughout our RSPS scene, we have scene force chatting being done in multiple ways. Some used process, some made their own system. I, for one, am not sure what type of design you can use without the use of process. Maybe the NPC tick task, update task, what? What would allow us to make a good system for yelling that'll give us the right speed (we make it say it every 3 seconds, so it will), yet still be efficient.
Your thoughts?

item.title: Designs for 'Yell' (Force Chat)
item.dc:creator: @Wintercanon Wintercanon
item.description:
@Wintercanon wrote:

Just have a queue of forced chat quotes, and pop one every ‘x’ amount of seconds and add it to the update block.

Read full topic

item.title: Designs for 'Yell' (Force Chat)
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

You misunderstood me, I am assuming that the task is going to be called more than once with the criteria being TRUE, each time that it is true that object is recreated. Which is unnecessary.

Read full topic

item.title: Designs for 'Yell' (Force Chat)
item.dc:creator: @King_JC King JC
item.description:
@King_JC wrote:

AtomicInt_:

butif it is true it will be created every time that is is true, over and over.

That’s what I want it to do.

AtomicInt_:

Slow down, you keep them within method bodies? That is creating unnecessary objects.

[quote=“King JC, post:22, topic:533257”] if (criteria()) { Clock clock = new Clock(); clock.getClock(); }

If criteria = false, are you telling me it still creates the new Clock instance?[/quote]

AtomicInt_:

No, if it is false it does not get created

So it does create unnecessary objects, then it doesn’t.

Read full topic

item.title: Designs for 'Yell' (Force Chat)
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

My example was leaning towards more of a do logic then release resources (like a Closeable)

Read full topic

item.title: Designs for 'Yell' (Force Chat)
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

when objects are no longer being used (based on scope of initialized variable and a few other factors) they are collected by the garbage collector. your example is wrong, atomic, you don’t need to do that.

[code=java]

class SomeTask {
void execute() {
Object object = new Object();
object.doStuff();
object.doOtherStuff();
//object is not stored to any variable that can be accessed from outside the method. after this execute() method is complete object will be collected by the GC
}
}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Designs for 'Yell' (Force Chat)
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

No, if it is false it does not get created, butif it is true it will be created every time that is is true, over and over.
What I meant was setting them to null after use; so:

class SomeTask { void execute() { Object object = new Object(); try { ... logic ... } finally { object = null; } } }

Don’t use this example directly, it was merely an example.

Read full topic

item.title: Designs for 'Yell' (Force Chat)
item.dc:creator: @King_JC King JC
item.description:
@King_JC wrote:

if (criteria()) {
    Clock clock = new Clock();
    clock.getClock();
}

If criteria = false, are you telling me it still creates the new Clock instance? I assumed it stopped reading if criteria = false, because why go any further. That’s inefficient if it does. Serious question, does it?

I can’t set the specific Objects that I am talking about, in my server, to null because they are on a repeated event loop. If I null them, they stop doing what I want them to do, and it ends the loop.

Read full topic

item.title: Designs for 'Yell' (Force Chat)
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

King JC:

I keep all new instances of Objects local/inside if-else statements so I don’t create any unnecessary Objects if the criteria isn’t met.

Slow down, you keep them within method bodies? That is creating unnecessary objects.

King JC:

I understand though that long term this may use up more memory as Objects won’t be cleaned, but nothing a weekly restart won’t fix. In Hyperion there is no other way to do things like this without reinventing the process() method.

What? You can let the garbage collector clean up objects, you can do this by setting the object to [tt]null[/tt] which basically tells the garbage collector that you are done with the object and it needs cleaned.

Read full topic

item.title: Designs for 'Yell' (Force Chat)
item.dc:creator: @King_JC King JC
item.description:
@King_JC wrote:

I submit a new task/tick to registerGlobalEvents() for things like my in game clock, water temperature variable (re-calculates every 5 minutes) etc., and I have no performance issues.

I keep all new instances of Objects local/inside if-else statements so I don’t create any unnecessary Objects if the criteria isn’t met.

I understand though that long term this may use up more memory as Objects won’t be cleaned, but nothing a weekly restart won’t fix. In Hyperion there is no other way to do things like this without reinventing the process() method.

Read full topic

item.title: Designs for 'Yell' (Force Chat)
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:

This thread honestly makes no sense.

item.title: Designs for 'Yell' (Force Chat)
item.dc:creator: @arham_4 arham 4
item.description:
@arham_4 wrote:

[quote=“Loveandpower, post:16, topic:533257”][quote author=Vain_ link=topic=652052.msg4371314#msg4371314 date=1380747003]

[quote author=Loveandpower link=topic=652052.msg4371252#msg4371252 date=1380737300]

[quote author=Arcik link=topic=652052.msg4371226#msg4371226 date=1380729856]

I don’t see why it shouldn’t just start up when a person enters a region and then ends when they leave that region? Wouldn’t that be more efficient then it having always processing the same event?

Because you would need another process checking the players location which may require an event/process w.e. then you would need another process for player/npc to send the text.
[/quote]problem? via the way regions are generally loaded these days I don’t see an issue with that one bit. Sure it may still lower performance a little but not nearly as much as you guys are talking about…
[/quote]but why would you want to load chat per region, when the npcs update in the regions anyway? just go about using the update block like people should.
[/quote]what?

still not seeing the problem but whatever :p[/quote]
If you do it via NPC update block, there would be no use in making it specific for region as the NPC update block is called only for players in the region anyways.

Read full topic

I don’t see why it shouldn’t just start up when a person enters a region and then ends when they leave that region? Wouldn’t that be more efficient then it having always processing the same event?

Because you would need another process checking the players location which may require an event/process w.e. then you would need another process for player/npc to send the text.
[/quote]problem? via the way regions are generally loaded these days I don’t see an issue with that one bit. Sure it may still lower performance a little but not nearly as much as you guys are talking about…
[/quote]but why would you want to load chat per region, when the npcs update in the regions anyway? just go about using the update block like people should.[/quote]what?

still not seeing the problem but whatever

item.title: Designs for 'Yell' (Force Chat)
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

Loveandpower:

I don’t see why it shouldn’t just start up when a person enters a region and then ends when they leave that region? Wouldn’t that be more efficient then it having always processing the same event?

Because you would need another process checking the players location which may require an event/process w.e. then you would need another process for player/npc to send the text.

item.title: Designs for 'Yell' (Force Chat)
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“Arcik, post:11, topic:533257”][quote author=Loveandpower link=topic=652052.msg4370933#msg4370933 date=1380634813]

lmfao, start a task on server startup or use the updating block…
[/quote]why would you make it on startup? that’s like making skype start up when the computer starts just slows it down doesn’t it?

How else would you initiate the task to run for everybody at same time? The task should only reduce startup by like 10ms if not that depending on how much data is being loaded. Skype is also runs on multiple threads so that’s mainly why it slows down startup.[/quote]I don’t see why it shouldn’t just start up when a person enters a region and then ends when they leave that region? Wouldn’t that be more efficient then it having always processing the same event?

Read full topic

item.title: Designs for 'Yell' (Force Chat)
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“Loveandpower, post:10, topic:533257”][quote author=Clawz fury link=topic=652052.msg4370916#msg4370916 date=1380627038]
lmfao, start a task on server startup or use the updating block…
[/quote]why would you make it on startup? that’s like making skype start up when the computer starts just slows it down doesn’t it?[/quote]

How else would you initiate the task to run for everybody at same time? The task should only reduce startup by like 10ms if not that depending on how much data is being loaded. Skype is also runs on multiple threads so that’s mainly why it slows down startup.

Read full topic

item.title: Designs for 'Yell' (Force Chat)
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

First of all the forced text will not show up if you do not set the force chat update flag; second if you want it timed you could modify the update block or use a Timer/TimerTask found within Java utilities.

Read full topic

item.title: Designs for 'Yell' (Force Chat)
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

Perhaps make it only yell when a player enters a region? I don’t see the point of making it always yell unless needed. As Vain/Arcik mentioned just use events when it’s in that region.

I’m assuming that’s the best way of doing it.

Read full topic

item.title: Designs for 'Yell' (Force Chat)
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“arham 4, post:1, topic:533257”]Throughout our RSPS scene, we have scene force chatting being done in multiple ways. Some used process, some made their own system. I, for one, am not sure what type of design you can use without the use of process. Maybe the NPC tick task, update task, what? What would allow us to make a good system for yelling that’ll give us the right speed (we make it say it every 3 seconds, so it will), yet still be efficient.

Your thoughts?[/quote]
Just saying, you said the wrong seen…

Anyways, I don’t use npc force chat of any sort, unless it’s for like when you’re fighting a boss and they have a specific shout out. Any other way doesn’t really need to be done.

Read full topic

item.title: Designs for 'Yell' (Force Chat)
item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_

use the npc updating block?
if you wanna change the time it takes, just use an int or double and increase or decrease in the update block, and perform the message at specific results.
